awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Ocean Sciences & Engineering at Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution 2019-2021 Program
awd_abstract_narration:
The Woods Hole Oceanographic Institute (WHOI) in Woods Hole, MA will host a Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site that will provide ten students with a ten-week active learning experience each summer for three years. Each Summer Student Fellow (SSF) is matched with an advisor(s) from one of the academic departments at WHOI.  Fellows work with their advisor to complete a work plan within their first few weeks of arriving at WHOI. During the summer, each SSF makes two presentations: a five-minute mid-summer oral progress report, and a final oral or poster presentation on their research. A written final project report is required. Professional development activities include a special lecture series, a one-day field experience on the R.V. Tioga, a half-day Responsible Conduct of Research workshop, training by the WHOI graphics department on how to prepare a scientific poster, and discussions about graduate school with a panel of postdocs and graduate students. Fellows are encouraged to publish papers in scientific journals and to present their research at scientific meetings after the internship is completed.

The WHOI REU Site will provide a total of thirty undergraduates with internships over the three-year period. The program conducts a national search for applicants and seeks to engage students who are from schools with limited research opportunities. Most of the funding provided supports student stipends, housing and travel to attend the program. The range of potential research projects for REU students at WHOI is extensive, with high-quality research conducted by the students in a wide range of disciplines and sub-disciplines. WHOI is one of the largest independent oceanographic institutions and research fleet operators in the world. Fellows use state of the art analytical instruments, sampling devices and modeling programs for their research projects in a wide range of disciplines, including biology, marine chemistry and geochemistry, geology and geophysics, physical oceanography, ocean policy and ocean engineering. Research themes that crosscut disciplines include oceans and climate, the changing Arctic, deep-sea exploration, ocean observing systems, biogeochemical processes and cycles, autonomous underwater vehicles and systems, seafloor processes and evolution, and human-ocean interactions and impacts. This project supports national goals of developing the next generation of scientists and the scientific workforce.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution (WHOI) Summer Student Fellowship (SSF) program is one of the NSF Research Experience for Undergraduate (REU) sites supported by the Division of Ocean Sciences of the National Science Foundation (NSF).  Funds provided by this three-year project supported undergraduate students participating in WHOI's Summer Student Fellowship program: ten Fellows in 2019 and 2020, and eleven Fellows in 2021.  Major goals of the WHOI SSF Program are to expose undergraduates to state-of-the-art research in ocean science and engineering and increase the participation of minorities underrepresented in ocean sciences. Students attend the 10-12 week program following their junior year. A combination of personal contacts with undergraduate faculty and former Fellows, material distributed at the WHOI booth at AGU, Ocean Sciences and other meetings, and pages on the NSF, WHOI, Institute for Broadening Participation, and SACNAS web sites are used to recruit students. Each Fellow is matched with an adviser(s) from one of the academic departments at WHOI, or from the U.S. Geological Survey. Each is encouraged to discuss potential projects with these potential advisors before deciding whether to accept the Fellowship offer.  Projects are carried out in a range of disciplines (Biological, Chemical, or Physical Oceanography; Marine Geology and Geophysics; Ocean Engineering; Marine Policy).  Fellows work with their adviser to complete a work plan within their first few weeks of the program (either at WHOI or, during 2020 and 2021, remotely).  During the summer, each SSF makes two presentations: a five-minute mid-summer oral progress report, and a final oral or poster presentation on their research. A written final project report is required. Professional development activities include a special lecture series, a one-day field experience on a small research vessel, a half-day Responsible Conduct of Research workshop, training on how to prepare a scientific poster, and discussions about graduate school with a panel of postdocs and graduate students.

The program has been successful in entraining STEM students from diverse backgrounds into ocean science and engineering, and efforts are frequently made to improve the program.  Information from an external evaluator is supplemented by input from individual exit interviews and an anonymous Exit Survey and used to modify subsequent year programming. 

During the pandemic, in the summers of 2020 and 2021, adjustments were successfully made to provide a valuable research experience. In 2020, advisors and students modified their projects to ones that could be done remotely, with loaner equipment, laptops, and/or hard drives sent to those who needed them to do their project remotely.  Many program elements were easily adapted to the Zoom platform, including a virtual R/V Tioga trip that was broadcast with live Q&A. In 2021, there was no problem finding enthusiastic advisors and mentors. To address cohort building (something identified as problematic in 2020),  a team of three graduate students met regularly over Zoom and Slack with the SSFs and had regular social activities. By the time the students arrived at WHOI for the one-week visit they already had established relationships, and these were enhanced by the visit. Additionally, to their credit more than ours, these students had clearly learned over the last year how to get the most out of remote learning. Despite the unprecedented circumstances, it became clear that the students were indeed gaining valuable research experience.  All of the students completed reports, gave excellent poster presentations, and gained valuable mentors.

The intellectual merit of this REU Site is the high quality of research conducted by the students in a wide range of disciplines and sub-disciplines.  WHOI is one of the largest independent oceanographic institutions and research fleet operators in the world.  Summer Student Fellows (SSFs) use state of the art analytical instruments, sampling devices, data analysis and modeling programs for their research projects in a wide range of disciplines.

Broader impacts of the WHOI SSF Program include engaging students in research to stimulate and sustain interest in science, introducing the fields of ocean science and ocean engineering to STEM students, and increasing diversity within ocean sciences.  Fifteen of the thirty-one students presented their research at national meetings; three are first authors and one a co-author of a paper published in a peer-reviewed journal. Of the twenty NSF-funded fellows from years 2019 and 2020, twelve are pursuing doctoral degrees, one a masters, two are in research technician positions, two are in K-12 positions, one became a house of representatives intern, one is at a non- profit, one is a Park Naturalist. These outcomes point to the success of the program in entraining STEM students into careers in the ocean and geosciences and/or engineering, and in working towards increasing diversity in these fields. Our SSFs are provided professional development opportunities to help them understand their graduate school and career options, and tracking since 2011 shows ~80% are in science graduate programs or working in a scientific/technical field.
